Consider a parameterized integral `a ‚Ü¶ ‚à´ x, f a x` where `f` is continuous and uniformly
compactly supported. Then the integral depends continuously on `a`.

type:
‚àÄ {E : Type u_3} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] {Œ± : Type u_6} {Œ≤ : Type u_7} [inst_1 : TopologicalSpace Œ±]
  [inst_2 : TopologicalSpace Œ≤] [inst_3 : MeasurableSpace Œ≤] [inst_4 : OpensMeasurableSpace Œ≤]
  {Œº : MeasureTheory.Measure Œ≤} [inst_5 : NormedSpace ‚Ñù E] {f : Œ± ‚Üí Œ≤ ‚Üí E} {s : Set Œ±} {k : Set Œ≤}
  [inst_6 : MeasureTheory.IsFiniteMeasureOnCompacts Œº],
  IsCompact k ‚Üí
    ContinuousOn (Function.uncurry f) (s √óÀ¢ Set.univ) ‚Üí
      (‚àÄ (p : Œ±) (x : Œ≤), p ‚àà s ‚Üí x ‚àâ k ‚Üí f p x = 0) ‚Üí ContinuousOn (fun a => ‚à´ (x : Œ≤), f a x ‚àÇŒº) s
name: continuousOn_integral_of_compact_support
docString:
Consider a parameterized integral `a ‚Ü¶ ‚à´ x, f a x` where `f` is continuous and uniformly
compactly supported. Then the integral depends continuously on `a`.

If a real-valued function `f` is interval integrable and continuous at `a` with strongly measurable derivatives `-f(a)` at `a` for both the left and right limits, then the function `x ‚Ü¶ ‚à´(a, x) f(t) dt` has these values as derivatives.

type:
‚àÄ {E : Type u_3} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ‚Ñù E] [inst_2 : CompleteSpace E] {f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí E}
  {a b : ‚Ñù},
  IntervalIntegrable f MeasureTheory.volume a b ‚Üí
    ‚àÄ {s t : Set ‚Ñù} [inst_3 : intervalIntegral.FTCFilter a (nhdsWithin a s) (nhdsWithin a t)],
      StronglyMeasurableAtFilter f (nhdsWithin a t) MeasureTheory.volume ‚Üí
        ContinuousWithinAt f t a ‚Üí HasDerivWithinAt (fun u => ‚à´ (x : ‚Ñù) in u..b, f x) (-f a) s a
name: intervalIntegral.integral_hasDerivWithinAt_left
docString: If a real-valued function `f` is interval integrable and continuous at `a` with strongly measurable derivatives `-f(a)` at `a` for both the left and right limits, then the function `x ‚Ü¶ ‚à´(a, x) f(t) dt` has these values as derivatives.

The Fundamental Theorem of Calculus-1 states that if a function `f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí E` is interval integrable on `a..b` (that is, it is integrable on both intervals `(a, b]` and `(b, a]`) and is continuous at `a`, then the function defined by `u ‚Ü¶ ‚à´ x in u..b, f x` has a derivative at `a` which is `-f a`. Here, `E` is a normed additively commutative group which is also a normed space over the real numbers and is complete. The function `f` is strongly measurable at a neighborhood filter of `a` with respect to the Lebesgue measure.

type:
‚àÄ {E : Type u_3} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ‚Ñù E] [inst_2 : CompleteSpace E] {f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí E}
  {a b : ‚Ñù},
  IntervalIntegrable f MeasureTheory.volume a b ‚Üí
    StronglyMeasurableAtFilter f (nhds a) MeasureTheory.volume ‚Üí
      ContinuousAt f a ‚Üí HasDerivAt (fun u => ‚à´ (x : ‚Ñù) in u..b, f x) (-f a) a
name: intervalIntegral.integral_hasDerivAt_left
docString: The Fundamental Theorem of Calculus-1 states that if a function `f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí E` is interval integrable on `a..b` (that is, it is integrable on both intervals `(a, b]` and `(b, a]`) and is continuous at `a`, then the function defined by `u ‚Ü¶ ‚à´ x in u..b, f x` has a derivative at `a` which is `-f a`. Here, `E` is a normed additively commutative group which is also a normed space over the real numbers and is complete. The function `f` is strongly measurable at a neighborhood filter of `a` with respect to the Lebesgue measure.

If a function is locally integrable, then it is integrable on any compact set.

type:
‚àÄ {X : Type u_1} {E : Type u_3} [inst : MeasurableSpace X] [inst_1 : TopologicalSpace X] [inst_2 : NormedAddCommGroup E]
  {f : X ‚Üí E} {Œº : MeasureTheory.Measure X} {k : Set X},
  MeasureTheory.LocallyIntegrable f ‚Üí IsCompact k ‚Üí MeasureTheory.IntegrableOn f k
name: MeasureTheory.LocallyIntegrable.integrableOn_isCompact
docString: If a function is locally integrable, then it is integrable on any compact set.

For any locally finite measure Œº on the real numbers and any constant function f(x) = c, the function is integrable with respect to Œº on any interval [a, b].

type:
‚àÄ {E : Type u_3} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] {a b : ‚Ñù} {Œº : MeasureTheory.Measure ‚Ñù}
  [inst_1 : MeasureTheory.IsLocallyFiniteMeasure Œº] {c : E}, IntervalIntegrable (fun x => c) Œº a b
name: intervalIntegrable_const
docString: For any locally finite measure Œº on the real numbers and any constant function f(x) = c, the function is integrable with respect to Œº on any interval [a, b].

This theorem states that for any natural number `n`, any type `E` that forms a normed additive commutative group, any constant function `a : E`, and any functions `c : Fin n ‚Üí ‚ÑÇ` and `R : Fin n ‚Üí ‚Ñù`, the constant function is integrable on the generalized torus. In other words, the integrability of the composition of the constant function and a torus map (defined by `c` and `R`) over the interval from 0 to \(2\pi\) (for all components) is guaranteed.

type:
‚àÄ {n : ‚Ñï} {E : Type u_1} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] (a : E) (c : Fin n ‚Üí ‚ÑÇ) (R : Fin n ‚Üí ‚Ñù),
  TorusIntegrable (fun x => a) c R
name: TorusIntegrable.torusIntegrable_const
docString: This theorem states that for any natural number `n`, any type `E` that forms a normed additive commutative group, any constant function `a : E`, and any functions `c : Fin n ‚Üí ‚ÑÇ` and `R : Fin n ‚Üí ‚Ñù`, the constant function is integrable on the generalized torus. In other words, the integrability of the composition of the constant function and a torus map (defined by `c` and `R`) over the interval from 0 to \(2\pi\) (for all components) is guaranteed.

The Fourier integral of an `L^1` function is a continuous function.

A holomorphic function on a compact complex manifold is locally constant.

‚àÄ {E : Type u_1} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ‚ÑÇ E] {F : Type u_2} [inst_2 : NormedAddCommGroup F]

If `f` is a locally integrable real-valued function on `Ioi 0` which is `O(x ^ (-a))` at `‚àû`
and `O(x ^ (-b))` at `0`, then its Mellin transform integral converges for `b < s < a`.

  MeasureTheory.LocallyIntegrableOn f (Set.Ioi 0) ‚Üí

      s < a ‚Üí
        (f =O[nhdsWithin 0 (Set.Ioi 0)] fun x => x ^ (-b)) ‚Üí
          b < s ‚Üí MeasureTheory.IntegrableOn (fun t => t ^ (s - 1) * f t) (Set.Ioi 0)
